content.body: Kaiido: that's the result of partitioning: https://privacycg.github.io/storage-partitioning/
Kaiido: coupled with popups being an odd exception of sorts that we'll hopefully be able to address in some way
content.formatted_body: Kaiido: coupled with popups being an odd exception of sorts that we'll hopefully be able to address in some way

content.body: annevk: Thanks. Would you have time to compose an answer there? While I could link to https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/5803 I don't feel confident enough to explain in which case this partitioning happens.
content.formatted_body: annevk: Thanks. Would you have time to compose an answer there? While I could link to https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/5803 I don't feel confident enough to explain in which case this partitioning happens.

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: I'm not really sure what you're trying to say in https://github.com/WICG/scroll-to-text-fragment/issues/234#issuecomment-2200440415
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: I'm not really sure what you're trying to say in https://github.com/WICG/scroll-to-text-fragment/issues/234#issuecomment-2200440415

content.body: annevk: I'm saying that if a site adds text fragment to a URL, it's not up to the web platform to hide it from scripts
content.formatted_body: annevk: I'm saying that if a site adds text fragment to a URL, it's not up to the web platform to hide it from scripts

content.body: ... mainly because it's not feasible to do it in a non-leaky manner
(the navigation timing bug is not the important bit here)
Noam Rosenthal: how does it leak today?
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: how does it leak today?

content.body: annevk:  copy the link to another browser?
content.formatted_body: annevk: copy the link to another browser?

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: how does that leak it to script?
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: how does that leak it to script?

content.body: the other browsers don't hide it
you have to assume all browsers implement the text fragment feature for this hiding property to work
I don't think Gecko not implementing (which I don't think will remain true for long) is sufficient to just remove all privacy properties
annevk: it's also that some scripts use this for good reasons like enhancing the UI
content.formatted_body: annevk: it's also that some scripts use this for good reasons like enhancing the UI

content.body: annevk: since scroll position is anyway exposed, this is kind of a weird feature where the web page knows something about where it was scrolled to and can infer things about it but has to go about it in non-straightforward ways
content.formatted_body: annevk: since scroll position is anyway exposed, this is kind of a weird feature where the web page knows something about where it was scrolled to and can infer things about it but has to go about it in non-straightforward ways

content.body: All of that was known when the feature was designed. Doesn't seem like there's enough here to revisit that.
Did you discuss this with Google Search? Cause I'm pretty certain they care about these properties as well.
annevk: agreed, I should get back to the internal conversation about this before proceeding the external one.
content.formatted_body: annevk: agreed, I should get back to the internal conversation about this before proceeding the external one.
